title: Ticket #826: Expected job lease duration != measured
description:
The expected job_lease_duration from reading the manual was 20 minutes yet measured = 30 minutes.

To repro:

1.) Start up a couple of sleep jobs

2.) condor_off -master

3.) wait 30 minutes

4.) scan the master, and starter logs timestamps

= exactly 30 minutes.

nothing is special about condor_config or submission
remarks:
upon further investigation the setting the job_lease_duration during submission does not affect the test scenario at all, and it will always wait 30 minutes.

To add to the weirdness, sometimes the startd does not cleanly exit and segfaults. Traces and logs will be attached.

2009-Oct-08 15:23:59 by tstclair:
Also, you can't restart using condor_master in the attempt to recover. You will need to send a QUIT (fast) then try again. Which means that condor will need to rerun those jobs, even though they may have finished.

2009-Oct-13 09:39:42 by danb:
Thanks for the careful detective work, Tim!

How about just getting rid of the call to cancelLeaseTimer() from ResState::leave_action()? The Claim object cancels the timer when the claim is destructed. It seems overly complicated to me to cancel it from within the startd state machine.

Also, this patch appears to touch a completely unrelated file condor_master.V6/masterDaemon.cpp.

2009-Oct-13 10:24:01 by tstclair:
I've added a TODO for future evaluation.

I've also verified that the commit only contains the relevant changes, I'm still getting used to a clean workflow with git when I'm working on multiple changes, my apologies about the patch.
